# ;inna; and its sisters

;wip_warn;

## Introduction

The ;arch; ;j_ism; is governed by an abstract ;pregov; that governs
a ;mubtada; and its ;xabar;, both in the ;ustate;.

For example:

(@inna_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans} . 

In example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun)
above, an abstract ;pregov; governs the ;mubtada;
[زَيْد]{.ar}
and
its ;xabar;
[قَائِم]{.ar}
both in the ;ustate;.

;inna; and its sisters
are a set of six ;pregov; particles
that take an ;arch; ;j_ism; as their input and
transform it, by governing
the ;mubtada; in the ;ustate; and the ;xabar; in the ;ustate;.
Furthermore, each particle has its own meaning that it imparts to the input sentence.

For example, the particle ;inna; can take 
example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
as input and transform it into:

(@inna_zaydan_qaaimun) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans} . 

As you can see,
the ;pregov; particle ;inna;
has transformed the input example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun)
by governing the ;ism_of;
[زَيْد]{.ar} in the ;astate;
and
its ;xabar;
[قَائِم]{.ar} in the ;ustate;.
It has also added the assertive meaning "[indeed]{.trans}".

<!--
When the ;ism_of; of ;inna; or its sisters is a pronoun,
then then the attached pronouns are used.
(This is discussed in more detail in section\ (ref) below.)
For example:

(@) [إِنَّكَ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed you are standing.]{.trans} . 
-->


The set of
;inna; and its sisters
is:

  i. ;inna; [indeed]{.trans}
 ii. ;anna; [that]{.trans}
iii. ;ka_anna; [as if]{.trans}
 iv. ;lakinna; [but]{.trans}
  v. ;layta; [would that]{.trans}
 vi. ;la3alla; [perhaps]{.trans}

We will discuss them in the following sections.

## ;inna; [inna]{.trn}

<!--
(@inna_zaydun_qaaimun) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans}
-->

### Basic meaning of ;inna;

;inna; has an assertive meaning.
It asserts the property which its ;xabar; expresses about its ;ism_of;.

;inna; is also a means for a sentence to begin with an indefinite ;ism_of;
(after ;inna; itself, of course).
For example:
-->

The above rules, which allow adding or dropping a [ن]{.ar},
are common for all of the sisters of ;inna;,

### An ;inna; as part of a larger sentence

An ;inna; sentence can itself,
be a part of a larger sentence.
For example:

(@) [زَيْدٌ إِنَّهُ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/355](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/354#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- indeed he is standing.]{.trans}  
    (The sentence [إِنَّهُ قَائِمٌ]{.ar} is the ;xabar; of the ;mubtada; [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.)

We will explore this more in section\ (inna vs anna) below).

## ;anna; [anna]{.trn}

### Interpretation of the ;anna; clause as a ;masdar; construction

;anna; may be translated as "[that]{.trans}".
;anna; is unique amongst
;inna; and its sisters
that when it transforms an input ;j_ism;
the output is actually not a ;isnaad_comp; sentence anymore.
Here is its output after transforming example (@inna_zaydun_qaaimun):

(@anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [that Zayd is standing]{.trans}

As you can see above,
example (@anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
does not stand by itself as a complete sentence.
Terminologically,
[زَيْدًا]{.ar}
is the ;ism_of; of ;anna;
and 
[قَائِمٌ]{.ar} is
its ;xabar;.
But once ;anna; has been added to the sentence, then the resulting output actually
only constitutes a single structural element of a sentence.
Let's explain what we mean
by making example (@anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
a part of a larger sentence:

<!--
In order to make example () structutally complete
it has to be part of a larger sentence.
So for example, we could say:
-->

(@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [يُعْجِبُنِي أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [That Zayd is standing pleases me.]{.trans}

Now the sentence is ;isnaad_comp;.
In this sentence,
the ;anna; clause
(i.e. ;anna;, its ;ism_of;, and its ;xabar; together)
structurally constitutes the ;musnadi; of the sentence
as the ;faa3il; of the verb
[يُعْجِبُنِي]{.ar}.
The verb
[يُعْجِبُنِي]{.ar}
is the ;musnad; of the sentence.

The grammarians have theorized that 
the ;anna; clause
is able to constitute a single structural element
by interpreting it as a
;masdar; construction.
And the ;masdar; is then able to take the place of the single structural element of the sentence.
In example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
the ;masdar; interpretation of
the ;anna; clause
[أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
[that Zayd is standing]{.trans}
is theorized as
[قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
[Zayd's standing(ness)]{.trans}.
If we replace 
the ;anna; clause
in example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun)
with this interpreted ;masdar; construction,
we get:

(@) [يُعْجِبُنِي قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd's standing(ness) pleases me.]{.trans}.

Now we can see how
the interpreted ;masdar; construction
[قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
constitutes the ;musnadi; of the sentence.
(Technically,
the ;mudaf;
[قِيَامُ]{.ar} is the ;musnadi; and
[زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
is it its ;mudafil; governee,
but loosely speaking they can be considered one unit.)

Because of this interpretation of
the ;anna; clause
as a 
;masdar; construction,
;anna; is also known as
the _;masdar;i_ ;anna;.

We have already studied in chapter\ (ref) a similar ;masdar;i particle:
the ;nasibah; ;an;.
The ;masdar;i ;anna; and
the ;nasibah; ;an;
are actually closely linked and we will study some aspects of
their relationship in section\ (ref) below ;ia;.

By the way,
the interpretation of
the ;anna; clause
as a
;masdar; construction
does not mean that
the sentence with the
;masdar; construction
will have exactly the same meaning as the
sentence with ;anna;.
Rather the 
;masdar; interpretation only helps us analyze the sentence grammatically.
And it will also help us determine when we can use
the ;masdar;i ;anna; as opposed to other alternatives.

### ;anna; clauses as different elements of a sentence

Let's get back to
example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [يُعْجِبُنِي أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
[That Zayd is standing pleases me]{.trans}.
In this sentence,
as we just discussed,
[أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar},
because of its interpretation as
the ;masdar; construction
[قِيَامُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar},
constitutes a single structural element.
In
example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun),
it constitutes the ;faa3il; of a ;j_f3l;,
which is a ;3umdah; element.
But an ;anna; clause need not only constitute a ;faa3il;,
or a ;3umdah; element for that matter.
An ;anna; clause may constitute various elements of a sentence.
We will discuss them below:

#### The ;anna; clause as a ;faa3il; {.unnumbered}

We have already seen an example of
the ;anna; clause as the ;faa3il; in
example (@yu3jibuni_anna_zaydan_qaaimun) [يُعْجِبُنِي أَنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}.
Here is another example:

(@) [بلغني أن زيدًا منطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
    [[@qawa3id_shaykh_zadeh@ 1/176](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/185#p1)]{.citex}  
    [[The news] that Zayd is setting out has reached me.]{.trans}

If we replace the ;anna; clause with its interpreted ;masdar; we get:

(@) [بلغني انطلاق زيدٍ]{.ar}
    [[@qawa3id_shaykh_zadeh@ 1/176](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/185#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd's setting out has reached me.]{.trans}

#### The ;anna; clause as a ;naib; ;faa3il; {.unnumbered}

(@) [عرف أن السارق جريء]{.ar}
    [[nawh_waadiH 1/264](https://shamela.ws/book/10018/256)]{.citex}  
    [That the thief is bold was known.]{.trans}  

If we replace the ;anna; clause with its interpreted ;masdar; we get:

(@) [عرف جراءة السارق]{.ar}
    [[nawh_waadiH 1/264](https://shamela.ws/book/10018/256)]{.citex}  
    [The thief's boldness was known.]{.trans}  


#### The ;anna; clause as a ;mafulb; {.unnumbered}

The ;anna; clause can occur in the position of a ;mafulb;.
Here is an example:

(@) [عَلِمْتُ أنّكَ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}  
    [I knew that you are excellent.]{.trans}  
    
If we replace the ;anna; clause with its interpreted ;masdar; we get:

(@) [عَلِمْتُ فَضْلَكَ]{.ar}  
    [I knew your excellence.]{.trans}  

<!--
(@) [سمعت أن عَمْرًا عالمٌ]{.ar}
    [[@qawa3id_shaykh_zadeh@ 1/177](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/186#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I heard that [#eamr]{.trn2} is knowledgeable.]{.trans}  

If we replace the ;anna; clause with its interpreted ;masdar; we get:

(@) [سمعت عِلْمَ عمرو]{.ar}
    [[@qawa3id_shaykh_zadeh@ 1/177](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/186#p1)]{.citex}

ومفعولًا نحو: سمعت أن عَمْرًا عالمٌ، وهو مؤوّل بـ (سمعت عِلْمَ عمرو).

ومضافًا إليه نحو: عَجِبْتُ من أنّ بكرًا واقفٌ، وهو مؤوّل بـ (عجبت من وقوف بكرٍ)

like a ;mubtada; and a ;xabar;

#### The ;anna; clause in the ;istate;  {.unnumbered}

The ;anna; clause can occur after a preposition.
For example:

(@) [عَجِبْتُ من أنّ بكرًا واقفٌ]{.ar}
    [[@qawa3id_shaykh_zadeh@ 1/177](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/186#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that Zayd is stopped standing.]{.trans}  

If we replace the ;anna; clause with its interpreted ;masdar; we get:

(@) [عجبت من وقوف بكرٍ]{.ar}
    [[@qawa3id_shaykh_zadeh@ 1/177](https://shamela.ws/book/19236/186#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at Zayd's being stopped standing.]{.trans}  

The ;anna; clause can even occur as a ;mudafil;.
For example:

(@) [قَالَ أَيْنَ تُرِيدُ قَالَ أُرِيدُ أَخًا لِي فِي هَذِهِ الْقَرْيَةِ  قَالَ هَلْ لَكَ عَلَيْهِ مِنْ نِعْمَةٍ تَرُبُّهَا قَالَ لاَ **غَيْرَ أَنِّي** أَحْبَبْتُهُ فِي اللَّهِ عَزَّ وَجَلَّ]{.ar}  
    [@https://sunnah.com/muslim:2567a@]{.citex}  
    [[He said, "Where are you intending [to go]?" He said, "I intend [to go to] a brother of mine in this town." He said, "Do you have upon him a favor that [you are seeking repayment for]?" He said, "No, **except that** I have loved him [for the sake of] ;Allah; the Exalted and Glorious."]{.trans}  

#### The ;anna; clause as a ;mubtada; {.unnumbered}

The ;anna; clause as a ;mubtada; is not as common as the other categories,
and has some restrictions.
Generally, it won't begin the sentence.
Instead, its ;xabar; will usually precede it.^[See [@aljani_aldani@ 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1) for an exception. See also [@sharh_ashmooni@ 1/204 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11742/195) for another example.]
For example:

(@) [في ظني أنك فاضل]{.ar}
    [[@aljani_aldani@ 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}  
    [[It is] in my estimation that you are excellent.]{.trans}  
    ([في ظني]{.ar} is analyzed as a fronted ;xabar; and the interpreted ;masdar; construction
    [فَضْلُكَ]{.ar} [your excellence]{.trans} is the backed ;mubtada;.)

(@) [وَمِنۡ ءَایَـٰتِهِۦۤ أَنَّكَ تَرَى ٱلۡأَرۡضَ خَـٰشِعَةࣰ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/41/39@]{.citex}^[See @https://tafsir.app/iraab-daas/41/39@ and [@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 2/206 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/573).]  
    [And of His signs is that you see the earth stilled]{.trans}


(@) [أحقا أنك ذاهب]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 2/205](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/572)]{.citex}  
    [[Is it] really that you are going?]{.trans}  
    (The interpreted ;masdar; [ذَهَابُكَ]{.ar} is the ;mubtada;.
    [حَقًّا]{.ar} is analyzed as an adverb ;xabar;.^[See [@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 2/206 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/573).])

<!--
But when preceded by
[أَمَا]{.ar}
[OOO]{.trans},
then the ;mubtada; ;anna; clause is allowed to precede its ;xabar;.^[[@aljani_aldani@ 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]
For example:

(@) [أما أنك فاضل ففي ظني]{.ar}
    [[@aljani_aldani@ 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}^[See also [@sharh_ashmooni@ 1/204 (editor's footnote)](https://shamela.ws/book/11742/195)]
    [Verily, that you are excellent, then [it is] in my estimation]{.trans}  
-->

The ;anna; may even be an ;ism_of; of ;inna; and [كَانَ]{.ar}.
Examples:

(@) [كان في ظني أنك فاضل]{.ar}
    [[@aljani_aldani@ 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}  
    [[It] was in my estimation that you are excellent.]{.trans}  

As the ;ism_of; of ;inna;, the ;anna; clause must be separated from ;inna;:

(@) [إن عندي أنك فاضل]{.ar}
    [[@aljani_aldani@ 408](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/390#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed [it is your rank] with me that you are excellent.]{.trans}  
    i.e. [You are excellent in my sight.]{.trans}

#### The ;anna; clause as a ;xabar; {.unnumbered}

(@) [أمرك أنك ذاهب]{.ar}
    [[@aljani_aldani@ 409](https://shamela.ws/book/26099/391#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Your state-of-affairs is that you are going.]{.trans}  
    (The interpreted ;masdar; [ذَهَابُكَ]{.ar} is the ;xabar;.)

### The interpreted ;masdar; when the ;xabar; of ;anna; is a prepositional/adverbial phrase

Consider the following sentences,
where the ;xabar; of ;anna; is a prepositional or adverbial phrase:

(@) [عجبتُ من أن زيداً عندك]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 24/10](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/419)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that Zayd is at [your place].]{.trans}  
    (The ;xabar; of ;anna; is an adverbial phrase: [عِنْدَكَ]{.ar} [at your place]{.trans}.)

<!--
(@) [عجبت من أن زيداً في الدار]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 24/10](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/419)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  
-->

(@) [علمت أن زيداً في الدار]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  
    (The ;xabar; of ;anna; is an adverbial phrase: [فِي الدَّارِ]{.ar} [in the house]{.trans}.)


In such cases, the interpreted ;masdar; is general beingness, represented by the ;masdar;
[كَوْن]{.ar}
or
[اسْتِقْرَار]{.ar},
as
below:

(@) [عجبت من استقرار زيدٍ عندك]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 24/10](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/419)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at Zayd's being at [your place].]{.trans}  

(@) [علمت كون زيد في الدار]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew Zayd's being in the house.]{.trans}  

### The interpreted ;masdar; when the ;xabar; of ;anna; is a ;substantive;

Consider the following sentence,
where the ;xabar; of ;anna; is a ;substantive;:


(@) [علمت أن زيداً أسد]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that Zayd is a lion.]{.trans}  
    (The ;xabar; of ;anna; is a substantive noun: [أَسَدٌ]{.ar} [a lion]{.trans}.)

In this case as well, the interpreted ;masdar; can be general beingness:

(@) [علمت كون زيد أسداً]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew Zayd's being a lion.]{.trans}  

Or the interpreted ;masdar; can be formed from the ;substantive;, using the suffix
[ـِيَّة]{.ar} [-iyyah]{.trn}
(see section\ (ref)),
as below:

(@) [علمت أسدية زيد]{.ar}
    [[haazimi 37/15](https://shamela.ws/book/36130/688)]{.citex}  
    [I knew Zayd's lion-like-ness.]{.trans}  

### Optionally delete the preposition before ;anna;

When the ;anna; clause is in the ;istate; following a preposition,
then it is allowed to (optionally) delete the preposition, for the same meaning,
as long as the meaning remains clear.
So, instead of saying:

(@) [عجبت **من** أنك قائم]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 2/151](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/538)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at that you are standing.]{.trans}  

 we can say:

(@) [عجبت أنك قائم]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 2/151](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/538)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered that you are standing.]{.trans}

### [لِأَنَّ]{.ar} [because]{.trans}

The preposition [لِ]{.ar} when attached before ;anna; can signify the meaning
[because]{.trans}.^[@wright@ 1/293B]
For example:

(@) [قَالَ كَانَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم إِذَا أُتِيَ بِطَعَامٍ أَكَلَ مِنْهُ وَبَعَثَ بِفَضْلِهِ إِلَىَّ وَإِنَّهُ بَعَثَ إِلَىَّ يَوْمًا بِفَضْلَةٍ لَمْ يَأْكُلْ مِنْهَا **لأَنَّ** فِيهَا ثُومًا فَسَأَلْتُهُ أَحَرَامٌ هُوَ قَالَ لاَ وَلَكِنِّي أَكْرَهُهُ مِنْ أَجْلِ رِيحِهِ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/muslim:2053@]{.citex}  
    [He said, "The Messenger of ;Allah; ;pbuh; would, when he was brought some food, eat from it and send its extra to me. And indeed he sent to me, one day, some extra having not eaten from it **because** in it was some garlic. So I asked him, 'Is it unlawful?' He said, 'No, but I dislike it because of its odor.'"]{.trans}

## ;ka_anna; [kaEanna]{.trn}

;ka_anna; signifies [as if]{.trans}.
Examples:

(@) [كَأَنَّ الْعِلْمَ نُورٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/272]{.citex}  
    [[It is] as if knowledge is a light.]{.trans}  

(@) [كَأَنَّ عَلِيًّا أَسَدٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/272]{.citex}  
    [[It is] as if [#ealiyy]{.trn2} is a lion.]{.trans}  

(@) [ فَجِيءَ بِنَا كَأَنَّا أَفْرُخٌ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/abudawud:4192@]{.citex}  
    [So we were brought [and it was] as if we [were] chicks.]{.trans}  

(@) [كَأَنَّهُمۡ حُمُرࣱ مُّسۡتَنفِرَةࣱ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/74/50@]{.citex}  
    [As if they were alarmed donkeys]{.trans}

(@) [كَأَنِّي أَنْظُرُ إِلَى بَيَاضِهِ فِي يَدِهِ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:65@]{.citex}  
    [It is as if I am looking at its whiteness in his hand.]{.trans}  

## ;lakinna; [lAkinna]{.trn}

;lakinna; signifies [but]{.trans}.
It forms a complete sentence with its ;ism_of; and its ;xabar;.
But it will usually follow a previous sentence and contrast it.
Examples:

(@) [الشَّمْسُ مُشْرِقَةٌ لَكِنَّ الْجَوَّ بَارِدٌ]{.ar}  
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/272]{.citex}  
    [The sun is bright but the air is cold.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَالَ یَـٰقَوۡمِ لَیۡسَ بِی ضَلَـٰلَةࣱ وَلَـٰكِنِّی رَسُولࣱ مِّن رَّبِّ ٱلۡعَـٰلَمِینَ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/7/61@]{.citex}  
    [[Noah] said, "O my people, there is not error in me, but I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds."]{.trans}  

## ;layta; [layta]{.trn}

;layta; has a wishful meaning.
For example:

(@) [ليت زيداً قائمًا]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 4/568](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1932)]{.citex}  
    [Would that Zayd were standing.]{.trans}  

The ;ya_nida;
is frequently used before
;layta;.
For example:

(@) [قَالَ يَـٰلَيْتَ قَوْمِى يَعْلَمُونَ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/36/26@]{.citex}  
    [He said, "I wish my people could know"]{.trans}

When the ;ism_of; is a pronoun for the singular ;first;-;person; [ي]{.ar},
then a ;noon_wiq; is inserted by default.
For example:

(@) [وَيَقُولُ ٱلْكَافِرُ يَـٰلَيْتَنِى كُنتُ تُرَٰبًۢا]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/78/40@]{.citex}  
    [and the disbeliever will say, "Oh, I wish that I were dust!"]{.trans}  

Very rarely, the ;noon_wiq; can be omitted.^[[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 1/332](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/332#p1)]


And when 
the ;ism_of; is a pronoun for the plural ;first;-;person; [نَا]{.ar},
then the [ن]{.ar} of the pronoun is not dropped.
For example:

(@) [يَـٰلَيْتَنَآ أَطَعْنَا ٱللَّهَ وَأَطَعْنَا ٱلرَّسُولَا۠]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/33/66@]{.citex}  
    [How we wish we had obeyed Allāh and obeyed the Messenger.]{.trans}  
    
;anna; can be  combined with ;layta; thus:

(@) [**ليت أنّ** زيدًا خارجٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 4/569](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1933#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Would that Zayd were going out.]{.trans}  

(@) [لَيْتَ أَنَّهُ شَاعِرٌ]{.ar}
    [@fischer@ 180]{.citex}  
    [Would that he were a poet.]{.trans}

## ;la3alla; [laealla]{.trn}

;la3alla; signifies [perhaps]{.trans}.
It tends to be used in situations signifying hope for, or apprehension from, an impending event.^[[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 4/569](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1933#p1)]

Example of hope:

(@) [لعل زيدا يكرمني]{.ar}
    [[@maani_nahw@ 1/305](https://shamela.ws/book/17801/304)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps (i.e. I hope) Zayd will honor me.]{.trans}

Example of apprehension:

(@) [لعلّ بكرًا يضرب]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 4/570](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1934#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps (i.e. I fear) Bakr will beat.]{.trans}  

Opposite to ;layta;,
when the ;ism_of; is a pronoun for the singular ;first;-;person; [ي]{.ar},
then a ;noon_wiq; is not inserted by default.
For example:

(@) [إِذْ رَءَا نَارًۭا فَقَالَ لِأَهْلِهِ ٱمْكُثُوٓا۟ إِنِّىٓ ءَانَسْتُ نَارًۭا **لَّعَلِّىٓ** ءَاتِيكُم مِّنْهَا بِقَبَسٍ أَوْ أَجِدُ عَلَى ٱلنَّارِ هُدًۭى]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/20/10@]{.citex}  
    [When he saw a fire and said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire; perhaps I can bring you a torch or find at the fire some guidance."]{.trans}  

Very rarely, the ;noon_wiq; can be omitted.^[[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 1/333](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/333#p1)]

But like ;layta;,
the ;ism_of; is a pronoun for the plural ;first;-;person; [نَا]{.ar},
then the [ن]{.ar} of the pronoun is not dropped.
For example:


(@) [أَخْبِرْ صَاحِبَكَ أَنَّا قَدْ جِئْنَا **وَلَعَلَّنَا** سَنَعُودُ إِنْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:4359@]{.citex}  
    [Inform your companion that we came and perhaps we will come back, ;ia;.]{.trans}  

Here are some more examples showing the semantic range of ;la3alla;:

(@) [**لَعَلَّكُمْ** لَوْ لَمْ تَفْعَلُوا كَانَ خَيْرًا]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/muslim:2362@]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps if you did not do [it], it would be better.]{.trans}  


(@) [إِنَّكُمْ لاَ تَدْرُونَ **لَعَلَّكُمْ** أَنْ تُبْتَلَوْا]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/ibnmajah:4029@]{.citex}  
    [Indeed you do not know, perhaps you will be tested.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَالَ كُنَّا عِنْدَ عُمَرَ فَقَالَ أَيُّكُمْ سَمِعَ رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم يَذْكُرُ الْفِتَنَ فَقَالَ قَوْمٌ نَحْنُ سَمِعْنَاهُ فَقَالَ **لَعَلَّكُمْ** تَعْنُونَ فِتْنَةَ الرَّجُلِ فِي أَهْلِهِ وَجَارِهِ قَالُوا أَجَلْ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/muslim:144a@]{.citex}  
    [We were with [#eumar]{.trn2} and he said, "Which of you has heard the Messenger of ;Allah; mention the tribulations?" Some people said, "We did hear him." So he said, "Perhaps you are meaning the tribulation of a man in regard to his household and his neighbor?"]{.trans}  

;la3alla; can also be used for a past event.
For example:

(@) [**لَعَلَّكَ** قَبَّلْتَ أَوْ غَمَزْتَ أَوْ نَظَرْتَ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:6824@]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps you (only) kissed or winked or looked?]{.trans}  

(@) [**لَعَلَّنَا** أَعْجَلْنَاكَ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:180@]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps we have forced you to hurry?]{.trans}  

;la3alla; is often connected in meaning to a previous sentence.
signifying in its meaning a connotation of [in order to]{.trans}.
In this sense, it approaches the meaning of [كَيْ]{.ar}.^[See (with caution) also @https://tafsir.app/kashaf/2/21@ and @https://tafsir.app/ibn-aashoor/2/21@ [یَـٰۤأَیُّهَا ٱلنَّاسُ ٱعۡبُدُوا۟ رَبَّكُمُ ٱلَّذِی خَلَقَكُمۡ وَٱلَّذِینَ مِن قَبۡلِكُمۡ لَعَلَّكُمۡ تَتَّقُونَ]{.quran}]
For example:

(@) [فَلَمَّا قُبِضَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم فَخَرَجَ مُسَيْلِمَةُ الْكَذَّابُ قُلْتُ لأَخْرُجَنَّ إِلَى مُسَيْلِمَةَ **لَعَلِّي** أَقْتُلُهُ فَأُكَافِئَ بِهِ حَمْزَةَ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:4072@]{.citex}  
    [When the Messenger of ;Allah; ;pbuh; passed away, and then Musaylimah the Liar appeared, I said, "I will surely go out to Musaylimah **so that** I may kill him and so make amends for [killing] [#Hamzah]{.trn2}.]{.trans}  

## A prepositional/adverbial phrase as the ;xabar; of ;inna; and its sisters

A prepositional/adverbial phrase can occurs as the ;xabar; of ;inna; and its sisters.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا فِي الدَّارِ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  

(@) [عَلِمْتُ أَنَّ زَيْدًا عِنْدَكَ]{.ar}
    [Indeed Zayd is at [your place].]{.trans}  

In such cases,
based on what we have learned in section\ (ref),
the ;xabar; is actually implicated as general beingness,
and the preposition or adverb is its governee.
But loosely speaking we may say that
the prepositional/adverbial phrase is the ;xabar;.

## A complete sentence as the ;xabar; of ;inna; and its sisters

The ;xabar; of ;inna; and its sisters may be a complete sentence.
Examples:

(@) [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ يُعَزِّزُ صَاحِبَهُ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 272]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the knowledge -- it makes esteemed its companion.]{.trans}  
    (The ;xabar; of ;inna; is the ;j_f3l; [يُعَزِّزُ صَاحِبَهُ]{.ar} [it makes esteemed its companion]{.trans}.)

(@) [إِنَّ الْعَالِمَ قَدْرُهُ مُرْتَفِعٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/272]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the scholar -- his worth is high.]{.trans}  
    (The ;xabar; of ;inna; is the ;j_ism; [قَدْرُهُ مُرْتَفِعٌ]{.ar} [his worth is high]{.trans}.)

(@) [لَعَلَّكَ اجْتَهَدْتَ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/272]{.citex}  
    [Perhaps you may exert yourself.]{.trans}  
    (The ;xabar; of ;la3alla; is the ;j_f3l; [اجْتَهَدْتَ]{.ar} [you exert yourself]{.trans}.)

The ;xabar; of ;inna; (and its sisters) 
can even be a compound itself itself.
Here is an example where the ;xabar; of ;inna;
is a ;kaana; sentence with its own ;ism_of; and ;j_f3l; ;xabar;:

(@) [وَإِنَّ أَبَا هُرَيْرَةَ **كَانَ يَلْزَمُ** رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم بِشِبَعِ بَطْنِهِ وَيَحْضُرُ مَا لاَ يَحْضُرُونَ وَيَحْفَظُ مَا لاَ يَحْفَظُونَ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:118@]{.citex}  
    [And indeed [#abU #hurayrah]{.trn2} used to stick with the Messenger of ;Allah; with the fill of his stomach and be present for what they [were] not present for, and memorize what they [were] not memorizing.]{.trans}

## Word order of the ;ism_of; and the ;xabar; with ;inna; and its sisters

The ;ism_of; of ;inna; (and its sisters) must always follow it in word order.
And its ;xabar; must always follow the ;ism_of;.
So, for example,
we cannot say:

(@) ;x; [إِنَّ قَائِمٌ زَيْدًا]{.ar}
    [[@sharh_qatr_alnada@ 162](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/137)]{.citex}  

We must say instead:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans}

If the ;xabar; has a governee, then it too
should not, in general, preceded the ;ism_of;.
So we cannot say:

(@) ;x; [إن **طعامك** زيدا آكل]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  

We must say instead:

(@) [إن زيدا آكل **طعامك**]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is eating your food.]{.trans}  

The following word order is also permissible, for the same meaning:

(@) [إن زيدا **طعامك** آكل]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/317](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/978)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is eating your food.]{.trans}  

But when the governee of the ;xabar; is a prepositional or adverbial phrase,
then there is some diagreement amongst the grammarians.^[[@irtishaaf@ 3/1244](https://shamela.ws/book/16595/1244); [@sirafi_sibawayhi@ 2/464](https://shamela.ws/book/17726/962)]
Some grammarians allowed
sentences like:

(@) [إِنَّ **عِنْدَكَ** زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed with you Zayd is sitting.]{.trans}  

(@) [إن **بك** زيدا واثق]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in you Zayd is trusting.]{.trans}  
    
Others disallowed such sentences and mandated the following order^[[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ **عِنْدَكَ**]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is sitting with you.]{.trans}  

(@) [إن زيدا واثق **بك**]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/349](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/348)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is trusting in you.]{.trans}  

But when the ;xabar; is itself
(loosely speaking) the prepositional or adverbial phrase,
then then it may be placed before the ;ism_of; undisputably.
Sometimes, placing the 
prepositional/adverbial phrase
before the ;ism_of; is optional.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ فِي الدَّارِ ضُيُوفًا كِرَامًا]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/273]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in the house are noble guests.]{.trans}  

(@) [لَيْتَ عِنْدَكَ مُحَمَّدًا]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/273]{.citex}  
    [O that with you was [#muHammad]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

In such cases, where the prepositional/adverbial phrase ;xabar; may be placed either before or after the ;ism_of;,
the signification can be slightly diferent.
For example, if we say:

(@) [إِنَّ مَعَكَ صَاحِبَكَ.]{.ar}
    [@wright@ 2/80C]{.citex}  
    [Indeed, with you, is **your companion**.]{.trans}

This puts the logical accent on the ;ism_of; [صَاحِبَكَ]{.ar} "your companion". If the ;ism_of; is placed first then this puts the logical accent on the ;xabar;:

(@) [إِنَّ صَاحِبَكَ مَعَكَ.]{.ar}
    [@wright@ 2/80C]{.citex}  
    [Indeed your companion is **with you**.]{.trans}



When the prepositional/adverbial phrase has a pronoun that refers to the ;ism_of;,
then it must obligatorily be placed before the ;ism_of;.
For example:

(@) [إِنَّ فِي الدَّارِ سَاكِنَهَا]{.ar}
    [[@irtishaaf@ 3/1244](https://shamela.ws/book/16595/1244)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in the house is its resident.]{.trans}

(@) [إِنَّ عِنْدَ هِنْدٍ بَعْلَهَا]{.ar}
    [[@irtishaaf@ 3/1244](https://shamela.ws/book/16595/1244)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed with Hind is her husband.]{.trans}

## A ;damir_shan; as the ;ism_of; of ;inna; and its sisters

A ;damir_shan; can occur as the ;ism_of; of ;inna; and its sisters.
In this case,
as usual,
the ;xabar; will be a complete sentence.

As with ;kaana;, when the ;ism_of; is a ;damir_shan;,
then the ;xabar; can be a ;j_ism; or a ;j_f3l;.

For example:

(@) [**إِنَّهَا** تَكُونُ الظُّلْمَةُ وَالسَّيْلُ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:667@]{.citex}  
    [The state-of-affairs is: [there] is [at times] darkness and flooding]{.trans}  

(@) [وَقَالَ إِنَّهُ قَدِ اجْتَمَعَ لَكُمْ فِي يَوْمِكُمْ هَذَا عِيدَانِ]{.ar}  
    <https://sunnah.com/urn/504350>

## ;inna; with a ;laam_ibt;

The _;laam_ibt;_ is a particle which generally occurs in the beginning of a sentence signifies an assertive meaning.
For example, if we start with:

(@) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

then we can make the sentence more assertive by using ;laam_ibt; in its beginning:

(@) [لَزَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

The ;laam_ibt;, in sentences without ;inna; (as above),
is placed in the beginning of the sentence
and is attached only to the ;mubtada;.
If the ;xabar; were fronted, we wouldn't say:

(@) ;x; [لَقَائِمٌ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/353](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1014#p1)]{.citex}  


### The ;laam_ibt; placed before the ;xabar; of ;inna;

This ;laam_ibt; is frequently found used with ;inna;.
But instead of occurring before ;inna; thus:

(@) ;x; [لَإِنَّ]{.ar}

it is placed between the ;ism_of; of ;inna; and its ;xabar;, thus:

(@) [إِنَّ زَيْدٌ لَقَائِمٌ]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  


When [إِنَّ]{.ar} is used together with ;laam_ibt; as in the example above,
then the sentence signifies extra assertion,
compared to if had only ;inna; or only the ;laam_ibt;.

In a similar manner to example () above,
we can say:

(@) [إن زيدًا لفي الدار]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is in the house.]{.trans}  

The ;laam_ibt; 
has certain restrictions placed on its usage,
when used with ;inna;:

Firstly, it can only be used with ;inna; and not with any of its sisters.

Secondly, the ;inna; sentence should be an affirmative sentence, not a negative sentence.
So we cannot say:

(@) ;x; [إِنَّ عَلِيًّا **لَمَا** حَضَرَ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/288]{.citex}

Instead, we should say (without the ;laam_ibt;):

(@) [إِنَّ عَلِيًّا مَا حَضَرَ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/288]{.citex}  
    [Indeed [#ealiyy]{.trn2} was not present.]{.trans}

Additionally, when the ;xabar; of ;inna; is a ;j_f3l; with a ;madi; verb, then the ;laam_ibt; is not attached to the ;madi; verb.
But if [قَدْ]{.ar} is used before the ;madi; verb, then the ;laam_ibt; may be attached before it.
So we cannot say:

(@) ;x; [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ لَرَفَعَ قَدْرَ صَاحِبِهِ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/288]{.citex}  

But we can say:

(@) [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ لَقَدْ رَفَعَ قَدْرَ صَاحِبِهِ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/288]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the knowledge -- it has raised the worth of its companion.]{.trans}  

Or we can say without both the ;laam_ibt; and [قَدْ]{.ar}

(@) [إِنَّ الْعِلْمَ رَفَعَ قَدْرَ صَاحِبِهِ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/288]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the knowledge -- it raised the worth of its companion.]{.trans}  

This restriction is not placed on a ;xabar which is a ;j_f3l; with a ;mudarie; verb.
So we can say:

(@) [إن زيدًا **ليخرج** اليوم]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- he will go out today.]{.trans}  

When the ;mudarie; verb has [سَوْفَ]{.ar},
then grammarians have disagreed with regards tp allowing ;laam_ibt; to attach to it.^[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]

(@) [إن زيدا **لسوفَ** يقوم]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- he will soon stand.]{.trans}

Also, ;ghair_mutasarrif; ;madi; verbs are exempted from being restricted and may be used with ;laam_ibt; directly.
For example:

(@) [إنّ زيدًا **لنِعْم** الرجلُ]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- how excellent the man.]{.trans}  

(@) [إنّ عمرًا **لِبِئْسَ** الغلامُ]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- how wretched the boy.]{.trans}  

However,
;laysa; is a ;ghair_mutasarrif; verb, but ;laam_ibt; does not attach to it because of the
undesirableness of two [ل]{.ar}s coming togather.
So we won't say:

(@) ;x; [إنّ زيدًا **لليس** بقائم]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/352](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1013)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd -- he is not standing.]{.trans}  

When a governee of the ;xabar; is placed before it in word order
(but still after the ;ism_of;),
such that it comes between the ;ism_of; and the ;xabar;,
then ;laam_ibt; will attach to the fronted governee, thus:

(@) [إنّ زيدًا **لَفِى الدار** قائمٌ]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd, in the house is standing.]{.trans}  

<!--
(@) [إنك **لَعِندي** خطِي]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/354](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1015#p1)]{.citex}
-->

(@) [إن زيدًا **لطعامَكَ** آكلٌ]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/355](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1016#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd, your food he is eating.]{.trans}  

But if the governee of the ;xabar; is placed after the ;xabar; then the ;xabar; will have ;laam_ibt;, not its governee.
So we won't say:

(@) ;x; [إنَّ زيدًا آكلٌ **لطعامكَ**]{.ar}
    [[@sarraj_usool@ 2/235](https://shamela.ws/book/7365/739)]{.citex}  

Instead, we will say:

(@) [إنَّ زيدًا **لآكلٌ** طعامَكَ]{.ar}
    [[@sarraj_usool@ 2/235](https://shamela.ws/book/7365/739)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is eating your food.]{.trans}  

Also, if the ;ism_of; has a ;na3t; which occurs between it and the ;xabar;,
then again ;laam_ibt; is placed with the ;xabar;.
For example:

(@) [إِنّ زيدًا الفاضِلَ **لَقَائِمٌ**]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/355](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1016#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed the excellent Zayd is standing]{.trans}  

### The ;laam_ibt; placed before the ;ism_of; of ;inna;

So far, we have seen the ;laam_ibt; attached before the ;xabar; of ;inna;.
But,
if the ;xabar; occurs before the ;ism_of; in word order,
then ;laam_ibt; is actually atached before the ;ism_of;.
In this way, ;laam_ibt; again occurs between the ;ism_of; and the ;xabar;.
For example:

(@) [إن في الدار **لزيدا**]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/373](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/372)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in the house is Zayd.]{.trans}  

If the ;xabar; occurs after the ;ism_of; in word order,
but a governee of the ;xabar; occurs before the ;ism_of;,
then we have two options:
;laam_ibt; may optionally be attached before the ;ism_of; or before the ;xabar;.
For example:

(@) [إن فيها زيدًا **لقائم**]{.ar}  
    [إن فيها **لزيدًا** قائم]{.ar}  
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/357](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1018#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed in it Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

### The ;laam_ibt; with a ;damir_fasl;

If a ;damir_fasl; occurs between the ;ism_of; and the ;xabar; of ;inna;,
and a ;laam_ibt; is to be used, then
the ;laam_ibt; will be attached before the ;damir_fasl;.
For example, if we start with:

(@) [إن زيدًا هو القائم]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/357](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1018#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is the standing one.]{.trans}  

and we add ;laam_ibt;,
we get:

(@) [إن زيدًا **لَهو** القائم]{.ar}
    [[@shatibi_sharf_alfiyyah@ 2/357](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/1018#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Indeed Zayd is the standing one.]{.trans}  


## When to use ;inna; vs ;anna;

### The basic principle

The basic principle in choosing whether to use
;inna; vs ;anna; is:

* ;inna; is used to begin a complete sentence. As a complete sentence, it can then be a part of an larger sentence.
* ;anna; is used to begin a clause which is part of a larger sentence.
  The larger sentence,
  in order for its meaning to work,
  requires a ;masdar;i interpretation of the ;anna; clause.

In theory, this is a pretty clear demarcation.
But in practice it can be a little tricky to tell when to use ;inna; vs ;anna;.
Let's work through some examples:

(@) [نُطْقِي اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}  
    [@wright@ 2/256D, @ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/204, previously cited in section\ (ref)]{.citex}  
    [My utterance is "[#allAh]{.trn2} is sufficient for me."]{.trans}

In the example above,
<!--
the complete sentence
[اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}
[[#allAh]{.trn2} is sufficient for me]{.trans},
as a ;xabar;,
is the ;musnad; of the outer sentence,
with the ;mubtada;
[نُطْقِي]{.ar}
as its ;musnadi;.

In such a case,
because the ;xabar; is a complete sentence that stands on its own,
it can begin with ;inna; but not ;anna;.
-->
the sentence ;xabar;
[اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}
[[#allAh]{.trn2} is sufficient for me]{.trans},
is simply being reported as speech.
It's not an interpreted ;masdar; of the ;xabar; which is expressing a property about the ;mubtada;
[نُطْقِي]{.ar}.
Rather, the ;xabar;, as a complete sentence, is the complement of the ;mubtada;.
So it can begin with ;inna; but not ;anna;, thus:
[نُطْقِي إِنَّ اللَّهُ حَسْبِي]{.ar}.

Here are a couple more examples:

(@) [خَيْرُ الْقَوْلِ إِنِّي أَحْمَدُ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/355](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/354#p1)]{.citex}  
    [The best of speech is: Indeed I praise.]{.trans}  

(@) [قَوْلِي إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 1/325](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/327#p1)]{.citex}  
    [My saying is: Indeed he is excellent.]{.trans}  

But if the ;xabar; expresses a property about the ;mubtada;, not as a complete sentence,
but as an interpreted ;masdar;,
then ;anna; is used.
For example:

(@) [اعْتِقَادِي أَنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 1/325](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/327#p1)]{.citex}  
    [My belief is that he is excellent.]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [اعْتِقَادِي فَضْلُهُ]{.ar} [My belief is his being excellent.]{.trans})

In the example above, it is not exactly the sentence
[هُوَ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
"he is excellent"
which is my belief.
Rather my belief is his _being_ excellent.

Here are some more examples of a complete sentence with [إِنَّ]{.ar} in a larger sentence.
In all the examples,
the ;inna; sentence is part of the larger sentence, _as is_.
It does not need to be interpreted as a ;masdar; construction.

(@) [زَيْدٌ إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 1/324](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/326#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- indeed he is excellent.]{.trans}  

(@) [مَرَرْتُ بِرَجُلٍ إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_hisham_awdah_almasaalik@ 1/323](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/325#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a indeed-he-is-excellent man.]{.trans}  
    (The sentence [إِنَّهُ فَاضِلٌ]{.ar} is the ;na3t; of [رَجُل]{.ar}.)

(@) [أَحْتَرِمُ الَّذِي إِنَّهُ مُخُلِصٌ فِي عَمَلِهِ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/275]{.citex}  
    [I respect the one who -- indeed he is sincere in his work.]{.trans}  
    (The ;inna; sentence [إِنَّهُ مُخُلِصٌ فِي عَمَلِهِ]{.ar} is the ;silah; of the ;ism_mawsul; [الَّذِي]{.ar}. See chapter\ (ref).)

(@) [جِئْتُ وَإِنَّ الشَّمْسَ تَغْرُبُ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/276]{.citex}  
    [I came while the sun was setting.]{.trans}  
    (The ;inna; sentence [جِئْتُ وَإِنَّ الشَّمْسَ تَغْرُبُ]{.ar} is a ;hal;. See chapter\ (ref).)

Now let's again consider some tricky areas:

### When ;inna; or ;anna; occur as a ;mudafil;

Consider the following sentence:

(@) [اجْلِسْ حَيْثُ إِنَّ زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/355](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/354)]{.citex}  
    [Sit where -- indeed Zayd is sitting.]{.trans}  

In the above example
[حَيْثُ]{.ar} is an adverb of place (see chapter\ (ref)) which is a ;mudaf; to the sentence-;mudafil;
[إِنَّ زَيْدًا جَالِسٌ]{.ar}.
The ;inna; sentence does not require the ;masdar;i interpretation [جُلُوس]{.ar} for the meaning to work.

Now consider this sentence:

(@) [قَالَ كَعْبُ بْنُ مَالِكٍ لَمْ أَتَخَلَّفْ عَنْ رَسُولِ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم فِي غَزْوَةٍ غَزَاهَا قَطُّ إِلاَّ فِي غَزْوَةِ تَبُوكَ **غَيْرَ أَنِّي قَدْ تَخَلَّفْتُ** فِي غَزْوَةِ بَدْرٍ ...]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/muslim:2769a@]{.citex}  
    [[#kaeb ibn #mAlik]{.trn2} said, "I didn't remain behind the Messenger of ;Allah; ;pbuh; in any expedition that he went on, ever, except in the expedition of [#tabUk]{.trn2}, other than that I remained behind in the expedition of Badr ...]{.trans}

In this example, the ;anna; clause 
[أَنِّي قَدْ تَخَلَّفْتُ]{.ar}
is ;mudafil; of [غَيْرَ]{.ar}.
;anna; is used instead of ;inna; because, in order for the meaning to work,
the ;masdar; of [تَخَلَّفَ]{.ar} is interpreted, thus:
[غَيْرَ تَخَلُّفِي]{.ar}
[other than my remaining behind]{.trans}.

### In reported speech

When a sentence is reported as speech,
then it will typically begin with ;inna;.
For example:

(@) [تُعَيّرنا أنَّا قليلٌ عَدِيدنا **فقلتُ لها إنّ** الكرام قليلُ]{.ar}
    [[@nahw_wafi@ 1/650](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/649#p1)]{.citex}  
    [She reproaches us that we -- our number is few. So I said to her, "Indeed the noble are few."]{.trans}  

(@) [**فَقِيلَ لَهَا إِنَّهُ** النَّبِيُّ صلى الله عليه وسلم]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/bukhari:1283@]{.citex}  
    [Then it was said to her Indeed he is the Prophet ;pbuh;]{.trans}  

In the following example, the pronoun in [إِنَّهَا]{.ar} indicates indirect speech, yet still ;inna; is used instead of ;anna;:

(@) [قَالَتْ إِنَّهَا حُبْلَى مِنَ الزِّنَا]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/muslim:1695a@]{.citex}  
    [She said that she had become pregnant as a result of fornication.]{.trans}

The reason for using ;inna; instead of ;anna; is, again,
that that the reported speech is not interpreted as a ;masdar; in order to connect it to the verb [قَالَ]{.ar} before it.
Rather, the entire reported speech is, as is, the ;mafulb; of the verb [قَالَ]{.ar}.

With other verbs that may indicate reported speech, ;anna; is typically used.
For example:

(@) [صَلَّى بِنَا سَعِيدُ بْنُ جُبَيْرٍ بِجَمْعٍ الْمَغْرِبَ ثَلاَثًا بِإِقَامَةٍ ثُمَّ سَلَّمَ ثُمَّ صَلَّى الْعِشَاءَ رَكْعَتَيْنِ ثُمَّ **ذَكَرَ أَنَّ** عَبْدَ اللَّهِ بْنَ عُمَرَ فَعَلَ ذَلِكَ **وَذَكَرَ أَنَّ** رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم فَعَلَ ذَلِكَ]{.ar}
    [@https://sunnah.com/nasai:483@]{.citex}  
    [Sa'eed bin Jubair led us in prayer in Jam'. (He prayed) Maghrib, three Rak'ahs with an Iqamah, then he prayed 'Isha', two Rak'ahs. Then he mentioned that 'Abdullah bin 'Umar had done that, and he mentioned that the Messenger of Allah ;pbuh; had done that.]{.trans}  

The reason is that now, the ;masdar;i meaning of the speech is interpreted as the ;mafulb; of [ذَكَرَ]{.ar}.
That is, [he mentioned [#3abd] ;Allah;'s **doing** that]{.trans}.

Ocassionally, we will find ;anna; used with [قَالَ]{.ar}.
And that is when [قَالَ]{.ar} is not simply reporting speech,
but signifying the speaker's belief, estimation, or claim of the _;masdar;i content_ of the following speech.^[[@nahw_wafi@ 1/650](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/649#p1); see also [@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 4/319](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1683)]
For example:
    

(@) [أتقول المراصدُ **أن** الجو بارد فى الأسبوع المقبل]{.ar}
    [[@nahw_wafi@ 1/650](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/649#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Does the forecaster say that the weather is cold in the upcoming week?]{.trans}  
    (i.e. [Does the forecaster estimate the weather to **be** cold ...]{.trans})

### After ;af3aal_quloob;

After, ;af3aal_quloob; (see chapter\ (ref),
if a sentence suspends its government (see section\ (ref)),
then either ;inna; or ;anna; may be used.
For example:

(@) [علمت **إن** الرياءَ بلاءٌ]{.ar}  
    [علمت **أَن** الرياءَ بلاءٌ]{.ar}  
    [[@nahw_wafi@ 1/651](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/650#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew that showing off is a trial.]{.trans}  

If ;laam_ibt; is used, then, of course; it would only be used with ;inna; not ;anna;.
For example:

(@) [علمت **إن** الإسراف **لطريق** الفقر]{.ar}
    [[@nahw_wafi@ 1/651](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/650#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew indeed extravagance is the path to poverty.]{.trans}  

### After ;idh_sudden;

After ;idh_sudden;
(see chapter\ (ref)),
either ;inna; or ;anna; may be used^[@nahw_arabi@ 1/277; [@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/356](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/355#p1). Also see editor's footnote.]:

(@) [خرجت فإذا **إن** زيدا قائم]{.ar}  
    [خرجت فإذا **أن** زيدا قائم]{.ar}  
    [[@ibn_aqil_alfiyyah@ 1/356](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/355#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I came out [and] suddenly Zayd was standing.]{.trans}  

### After an oath

### After [ف]{.ar} in a ;jawab_shart;

When the ;jawab_shart; begins with a [فَ]{.ar},
either ;inna; or ;anna; (or neither) may be used.^[@nahw_arabi@ 1/279]
For example:

(@) [إِنْ تَجْتَهِدْ فَإِنَّكَ/فَأَنَّكَ نَاجِحٌ]{.ar}
    [@nahw_arabi@ 1/279]{.citex}  
    [If you exert yourself then you will be successful.]{.trans}

## The ;muxaffaf; ;in;

@nahw_arabi@ 296

The particles
;inna;, ;anna;, ;ka_anna;, and ;lakinna;,
because of the ;shaddah; on the [ن]{.ar}, can be termed _heavy_.
They have
have ;muxaffaf; versions:
;in;, ;an;, ;ka_an;, and ;lakin;.
The ;muxaffaf; particles have somewhat different rules from their original heavy counterparts.
In this section we will treat the ;muxaffaf; ;in;.
We will treat the rest of the ;muxaffaf; particles in subsequent sections, ;ia;.


## The ;muxaffaf; ;an;

The ;muxaffaf; ;an; is to be distinguished from the light ;nasibah; ;an;
(which governs a ;mudarie; verb in the ;astate;).


## Differentiating between the ;muxaffaf; an and the ;nasibah; ;an;

;anna;, like ;inna; essentially signifies an assertive meaning.

<https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3600>:

::: {.ar}
والذي تقرر عند أصحابنا أن شرط عمل هذا المصدر أن يقدر بحرف مصدري والفعل، فقدر الحرف س بـ"أن" الثقيلة المسندة إلى ضمير الشأن؛ لأنه يعم أن تكون الصلة ماضية وحالاً ومستقبلة، فتقدر في الماضي: من أنه ضرب زيد عمراً، وفي المضارع: من أنه يضرب؛ لأنه يصلح للحال والاستقبال.

وقدره بعضهم بـ"أن" الناصبة للفعل؛ لأن صلتها تكون بالماضي، نحو: عجبت من أن قام زيد، وبالمضارع فتخلصه للاستقبال، نحو: عجبت من أن يقوم زيد. وبـ"ما"؛ لأنها تصلح للحال، وتوصل به، نحو: عجبت مما تضرب زيداً.
:::

<https://al-maktaba.org/book/31874/4114>

قَالَ السّهيلي: إذا قُلت: "كرهتُ خروجك" احتمل أن يكون المكروه نفس الخروج أو هيئته، وإن قلت: "كرهتُ أنْ خرجت" كان المكروه نفس الفعل

### [أن الناصبة]{.ar} with ;madi;

<https://shamela.ws/book/13301/2035#p1>:

::: {.ar}
قال الشارح: يريد أنّ "أن" الخفيفة ينسبك منها ومن الفعل الذي بعدها مصدرٌ، فيكون في موضع رفع بأنّه فاعلٌ، أو مبتدأٌ، أو في موضعِ نصب بأنّه مفعولٌ، أو في موضعِ مجرور بالإضافة.

فمثالُ كونها فاعلةً قولُك: "أعجبني أن قمتَ"، والمراد: قيامُك، وزمان ذلك المصدر المُضِيّ؛ لأن فعله الذي انسبك منه كان ماضيًا. وكذلك لو كان فعله مضارعًا، نحوَ قولك: "يسُرّني أن تُحسِن"، والمراد: إحسانُك، فهو مصدرٌ زمانُه المستقبل، أو الحال كما كان الفعلُ كذلك.
وتقول في المفعول: "كرِهتُ أن قمتَ"، أي: قيامَك، و"أكرَهُ أن تقوم".

وتقول في المجرور: "عجبتُ مِن أن قمتَ"، و"مِن أن تقوم".

ومجرَى و"أنْ" في ذلك مجرَى "أنَّ" المشدّدةِ، إذ كانت "أنَّ" مع اسمها وخبرها. في تأويلِ مصدر مشتقٍّ من لفظ خبرها. وتجري بوُجوه الإعراب على ما ذكرنا في "أن" المخفّفة، نحوَ قولك: "أعجبني أن تحسن"، أي: إحسانُك.

وقوله: "أن وما في حيّزها"، يريد: ما هو بعدها من تمامها، مأخوذٌ من "حيّزِ الدار"، وهو ما يتعلق بها من الحُقوق والمَرافِق، فاعرفه.

### ;anna; with meaning of ;la3alla;

<https://shamela.ws/book/9977/106>:

::: {.ar}
وتكون "إن": بمعنى "لَعَلّ" فِي قوله عزّ وجلّ: {وَمَا يُشْعِرُكُمْ أَنَّهَا إِذَا جَاءَتْ} ٢ بمعنى "لعلَّها إذا جاءت". وحكى الخليل: "إئتِ السوقَ أنْكَ تشتري لَنَا شيئاً" بمعنى "لعلَّك".

و"أنّ" إذا كَانَتْ اسماً كَانَتْ فِي قولك "ظننت أن زيداً قائم" فيكون "أن" والذي بعدها قصةً وشأناً، نحو "ظننت ذَاكَ" فيكون محلّه نصباً، وإذا قلْت "بلغني أن زيداً عالمٌ" فهذا فِي موضع رفع. وإذا قلنا "عجبت من أنّ زيداً كلّمكَ" فمحله خفض عَلَى مَا رتبناه من أنه اسم
:::
